occurrences.text: to the Lord Jesus Christ in Revelation 17, in verse 14. We read it in chapter 19, in verse number 16, that he is king of kings and Lord of lords. I mean, what a contrast that is given to us in verse 15 about our Lord, about the one who we're running for, the one that we're having our eyes on, compared the contrast to the Roman emperors that would have been obviously known during that day. No, no, no, no. Listen, we're serving God. We're not serving some man. We're not running a race for some man. We're not running a race for some Roman emperor. No, we're running the race for the only, that he is the blessed and only potentate. We're running a race for the king of kings and Lord of lords. Hallelujah. His position. In Isaiah 52, in verse number 7, the Bible says, thy God reigneth. Aren't you thankful this morning that our God is on his throne? We read in Revelation 19, in verse number 6, hallelujah, for the Lord God omnipotent reigneth. It really reminds me of how Paul, in the first chapter of 1 Timothy, turned back, if you will. It was our January memory verse. As Paul says this, in 1 Timothy 1 and verse 17, under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit of God, now under the king eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God,
